Harsh,
 
I think it would bring some benefit to tests to be able to report multiple
failures. However, it complicates the API significantly. Either we would
need a global variable to hold the current TestResult (which I am extremely
reluctant to do) or pass it explicitly to test methods and assertions. Your
example below would become:
 
public void testOrder(TestResult result) {

assertEquals(result, 9, Largest.largest(new int[] {9,8,7}));

assertEquals(result, 44, Largest.largest(new int[] {8,9,7}));

assertEquals(result, 32, Largest.largest(new int[] {7,8,9}));

}
 
In my opinion, this is one of those cases where costs outweigh benefits. If
Java had restartable exceptions, however, reporting multiple assertion
failures would be possible to implement cleanly. This is available in some
of the dynamic languages.
 
Sincerely yours,
 
Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

Hi,
Is there a way in jUnit to override the failfast behavior e.g. my code
looks like:

public void testOrder() {

assertEquals(9, Largest.largest(new int[] {9,8,7}));

assertEquals(44, Largest.largest(new int[] {8,9,7}));

assertEquals(32, Largest.largest(new int[] {7,8,9}));

}

I know the 2nd and 3rd asserts would fail. I want to see both results as
having failed in my results. But jUnit just stops at the first failure.

Is there any way to change this behavior?

Harsh.
